ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

DEREGULATION IN ELECTRICITY INDUSTRY
(Divestment of Tuas Power)


    1. Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will give an update on the progress of deregulation in the electricity industry; and what is the current status of the divestment of Tuas Power.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Sir, in 1995, the Government decided to restructure the electricity industry to make it a competitive market, but to achieve the final outcome in several steps over a period of time. As a first step, it corporatised the electricity and gas undertakings of the Public Utilities Board (PUB) on 1st October 1995 to form Singapore Power Ltd (SP). To facilitate further measures to introduce competition, SP was structured as a holding company with five separate subsidiaries. These are two generation companies (PowerSeraya and PowerSenoko), a transmission and distribution company (PowerGrid), a supply company (Power Supply) and a piped-gas company (PowerGas), each with its own board of directors and independent management. A new power station being built in Tuas was put under a separate company, Tuas Power Ltd (TP) owned directly by Temasek Holdings, so that it could compete against the SP generation companies.

    Since corporatisation, SP has performed well. SP has ventured overseas, while maintaining an excellent utility system in Singapore. Productivity has increased sharply. This has been achieved through the joint efforts of management and employees, and has enabled SP to offer $720 million in tariff rebates as part of the off-budget cost-cutting package in November last year.

    On 1st April 1998, we set up the Singapore Electricity Pool (SEP), which is an exchange for trading electricity.

Column: 1119

Since then, PowerSeraya and PowerSenoko have been competing to sell electricity through the Pool. More recently, Tuas Power Ltd has begun bidding to sell electricity into the Pool. TP's first 600 MW unit was commissioned on 1st March 1999. The second unit (also 600 MW) is expected to commence operation in January 2000. TP will begin constructing its second stage power plants soon, to be operational from year 2001 onwards.

    Besides TP, SembCorp Cogen has also been issued with a licence to generate electricity. The SembCorp Cogen power plant, when operational in year 2001, will generate 650 MW of electricity for sale into the Singapore Electricity Pool.

    After reviewing the progress of restructuring in the electricity industry, the Government has decided that as the next step, SP should fully divest its two generation companies in year 2001. SP will retain the transmission, supply and gas operations, which together form the large part of SP's business. PowerSenoko and PowerSeraya will be transferred to Temasek Holdings, the parent company of SP. Temasek Holdings may bring other suitable shareholders into one or both of the generation companies.

    This will separate the ownership of generators from the ownership of the transmission and distribution network. The generators are the contestable part of the industry. Competition between different generators is possible and should be encouraged, whereas the transmission grid is non-contestable, because it is a natural monopoly. This split between the contestable and the non-contestable parts of the industry will assure all generators of a level playing field and enhance competition in the industry.

    In view of this change in the structure of the power industry, Temasek Holdings is reviewing the divestment process of Tuas Power.

Column: 1120



    In making this decision to hive off PowerSenoko and PowerSeraya from SP, my Ministry has been mindful of its impact on SP and its staff. Government's intention to list SP and to structure the public listing as an asset enhancement programme remains unchanged. SP's regionalisation effort will also not be affected, as SP can still leverage on the expertise of generation companies within the Temasek group for overseas ventures.

    The restructuring will directly affect the employees of the two generation companies. SP management has therefore explained the plans to the union, which is the Union of Power and Gas Employees (UPAGE). The union has expressed to management workers' concerns, including job security, status of employment, and the terms and conditions of service. SP has assisted the union in getting the reassurance that this transfer is not a down-sizing exercise but a planned evolution of the power industry. Hence, there will be no change in the terms and conditions of the employment contracts, and no retrenchment at the time of ownership change. Employees of the generation companies will be treated fairly and will be no worse off as a result of the transfer. SP will work closely with the union to carry out the restructuring smoothly and with minimum disruption.

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar)(In Mandarin): Sir, if we had not preserved our own language and tried to learn our culture through the use of another language, can we retain the essence of our own culture? I think it will be very difficult.

    When I read the Chinese version of Shakespeare's works, I must first of all find out whether it was translated by the best translator. Even then, I cannot be sure whether the best translator can translate 100% of the quintessence of Shakespeare's works and the intricacies of the English culture at that time. Sir, it may not be very difficult to find a good Chinese translator. But, to get a very good Chinese translator who can genuinely understand the famous works of Shakespeare and the English culture will be extremely difficult.

    If, after reading the Chinese translation of Shakespeare's works, I tell my English-educated friends that I have already understood the quintessence and intricacies of the English culture, I will certainly make a laughing stock of myself. Likewise, if my English-educated friend tells me that he has read the English translation of the Chinese classics, and has therefore fully understood the quitessence of the Chinese culture, I will just dismiss it with a laugh.

    Sir, the bilingual language system implemented by the Singapore Government all these years is a very important education policy. It has at least trained Singaporeans to concurrently know two languages. If we say now that they know two languages (with English as the main language and mother tongue as the supplementary language) and our students will be able to understand the

Column: 1122

essence and intricacies of their own culture, it will hardly be convincing.

    Today, only very few Singaporeans are truly effectively bilingual. Most Singaporeans are proficient only in one language and concurrently know another language. If they only "concurrently know" and are not proficient in Chinese, they can speak and listen, but not so good in reading and writing, it will be very difficult for them to genuinely understand and preserve the quintessence of Chinese culture. They may perhaps feel that although they are not proficient in Chinese, they can still preserve the essence of Chinese culture through the use of other languages. This is unrealistic. I have spent a lot of time reading and studying a Chinese translation of the Holy Quoran. Until now, I can only say that I know the Islamic teachings of my Malay compatriots a bit more than before.

    Sir, personally I feel that people from different language backgrounds may be able to understand another language and culture through translation, but it will still be extremely difficult for them to fully comprehend the quintessence of that culture and strike up a sympathetic chord with it. In my view, most people can acquire only superficial understanding this way.

    In the ancient Chinese classic "Chronicles by Zuo Qiuming", there is a saying, " With the skin gone, what can the hair adhere to?" - meaning a person or thing cannot exist without a basis. Therefore, I urge the Ministry of Education to avoid thinking that one could learn the quintessence of his own culture through another language. Only if our students can make conscientious efforts to pragmatically learn their own mother tongue, can they preserve the essence of their own culture. Moreover, Chinese culture is rich and profound with great compatibility with and accommodation for other foreign cultures. This will indeed be very important for a multi-racial, multi-lingual society in Singapore. This will indeed be of great help to Singapore's future development.

Column: 1123



    Mr Ang Mong Seng (Bukit Gombak)(In Mandarin): Sir, the Prime Minister said in his National Day Message in 1997 that our standard of Chinese should be enhanced so that we can nurture our Chinese elite. This is very important because of the regional needs. The Chinese market is now open. To establish better trade relations with China, we need to have people who have good command of the Chinese language. The Chinese elite can also contribute in the fields of journalism, politics, education, the arts and the community.

    Every Chinese family should cultivate and practise Confucian teachings, such as honour the elder and respect the wise, filial piety and harmonious relations. In order to let the 5% of our students who have difficulties learning Chinese, the Government has proposed to set up a CL (B) programme to encourage them to carry on studying Chinese and learn their mother tongue. On the other hand, to attract more people to learn Chinese at a higher level, more students will be given the opportunity to take Higher Chinese.

    In a recent dialogue session of the Feedback Unit, out of 32 attendees, 27, ie, 85%, supported this move. I hope that the Ministry of Education would ensure that the principals and teachers of our schools will understand the intention of this new policy, give it their full support so that the new policy can achieve the desired results.
12.45 pm

    Sir, to produce students with a high Chinese standard, we need to have high quality teachers. As such, the Ministry of Education should take the training of Chinese teachers strictly and seriously. I would propose that the Ministry of Education set up a special college with Chinese elite lecturers to train our Chinese teachers to enhance their quality. At the same time, those who are now serving as Chinese teachers should be sent to this college or even overseas for specialised training, so that their standard of Chinese and their pedagogy can be further improved, and their professionalism

Column: 1124

enhanced. This is particularly important for Chinese teachers who are now 40 years of age and above. By now, they would have been teaching for some 20 years or more. They should be given the opportunity to attend some refresher courses to upgrade themselves.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether there is a long-term plan to ensure that we have sufficient qualified Chinese teachers to teach Chinese and Higher Chinese to meet our future challenge.

    Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Bishan-Toa Payoh)(In Malay): Sir, I wish to declare my interest. I am a teacher.

    Sir, the learning of the mother tongue has been made compulsory for students in all schools. Proficiency in the mother tongue will enable our students to inherit the culture of this community from the older generation. Recently, the Ministry of Education has decided to allow more Malay students to study Malay at Higher Malay level (HML) in secondary schools. This is most welcome by the Malay community. Today, 30% of the best Malay students at PSLE are allowed to take HML. More Malay students will have the opportunity to study Higher Malay at Secondary One level.

    Sir, in view of the increasing number of students, I would like to ask if the Ministry of Education has provided competent teachers to teach Higher Malay effectively. Following that move, I would like to ask if Higher Malay will continue to be taught at Junior College and whether Malay Studies in the National University of Singapore can be taught at Honours level.

    Sir, the Malay community needs students who are proficient in Malay who would take over from the current specialists in Malay such as Cikgu Mohamed Arif, Cikgu Masuri, Cikgu Suratman, and so on. I would like to ask the Minister for Education if the Ministry of Education will set up a committee to study the teaching and learning of Malay language in Singapore. This committee, I feel, will be able to make a study as to

Column: 1125

whether the Malay community wants an SAP school for Malay students or not.

    In my view, we do not need a SAP school for Malay students. What has happened to the two well-known Malay schools, ie, Sang Nila Utama and Tun Sri Lanang Secondary Schools, will be a lesson for our community. To me, the move by the Ministry of Education today to place the top Malay students in 12 of the best schools such as Raffles Institution, RGS, Tanjong Katong, Cedar and Victoria Schools, and so on, is a wise move. And I feel that if there are 30% of the top Malay students, the number will be about 500. Certainly, the number of schools allocated will be increased. At these schools, they will be able to compete with students from other races of equal calibre and maybe even better. So they will have the opportunity to study and interact with other races. We can expect this group of students, who will be scholars of the community, to be the professionals who will be the pride of the Malay community in future.

    I would like to propose that the Ministry provide additional teachers to teach Higher Malay (HML) in these schools. These schools will not only be able to teach Higher Malay and also outside the curriculum hours, they can introduce the Malay students to the culture, literature and heritage of the Malay community. In this way, we will ensure a group of Malay scholars who will be the role models of the younger generation.

    I hope the Minister could give consideration to these proposals.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast)(In Tamil): Sir, the Indian community welcomes the recent announcement by the Ministry of Education of a review of the teaching and learning of Tamil. In recent times, the Indian students, parents as well as Tamil teachers, have expressed much concern over this matter. The feedback is that the standard and content of Tamil language should reflect the fact that it is being taught and learned as a second language within the Singaporean context. Otherwise, students would lose the interest in their mother tongue and culture.

Column: 1126



    I would like to ask for the Minister's response to some key questions that are being raised at this early stage of the review. Firstly, will the review be completed in time for implementation in the year 2000 so that another academic year is not lost? Secondly, will the eligibility criteria to do Higher Tamil at the primary and secondary levels be broadened as it has been for Mandarin and Malay? Thirdly, will the scope of the review cover the recruitment, deployment and development of Tamil teachers? In particular, will the Ministry be considering initiatives to enable students to learn Tamil in their school during curriculum time rather than having to go to Tamil centres after school?

    I would like to ask the Minister for an update on the establishment of a Department for South-Asian Studies at the tertiary level. When will it start offering courses and will a Tamil module be included?

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, at a recent sitting of this House last year, I had said that the learning of our mother tongue gives us a sense of identity and bearing in our moral conduct. I thought then, and I still maintain now, that learning the mother tongue would help us preserve our cultural roots and give us a sense of identity. I also said then that the experience of the Chinese in Singapore is unique, only because we are geographically cut off from the others. Our experience may not be compared with the experience of the other ethnic Chinese in Taiwan, China or Hong Kong. There is, therefore, an increasing divergence in the manner in which cultural norms and practices are carried out. Two, three or four generations down the road, I am not sure if the Chinese in Singapore can say that we are culturally the same as the Chinese elsewhere in the world. Just take a look at the third and fourth generations of American born Chinese. If you listened to them speak with your eyes closed, you would be forgiven for mistaking that it is a non-Chinese who is speaking. How Chinese are they? Could their parents have prevented the tide of change by forcing the learning of the second language on them? Will their children or

Column: 1127

their grandchildren be as Chinese as they are 20 to 30 years down the road?

    The introduction of the SAP schools and the policy of producing a new breed of Chinese cultural elites to my mind only serves to slow down the inevitable tide of change. The cultural norms of the Chinese in Singapore will continue to evolve in a way that is totally divorced from the developments in Taiwan, China and Hong Kong. Yes, there will be the external influences from these countries. However, the development of the Chinese culture in Singapore will not be the same. We have to accept it. Up until now, there has to my mind never been any clear policy statement on the part of our Government as to the extent to which Chinese in Singapore should preserve their Chineseness vis-a-vis their mainland counterparts. Be that as it may, there are clear indications that we are losing our edge on our Chinese speaking ability. We learn that an increasing number of households in Singapore are using English as the language of communication rather than Chinese. Even in households where the parents speak Chinese well, English is often substituted as the language of choice. Just looking at some of the programmes hosted by our Chinese comperes, many Chinese-speaking friends of mine had commented that they are still some distance away from their counterparts in mainland China or Taiwan. Someone once said in an exaggerated manner if only to prove a point, that our counterparts on television in China rattle off at 1,500 words a minute whereas we rattle off at 800 words a minute, and even then, we make mistakes. This limitation on our ability in the Chinese language did not come by chance. Our people suffer from a real handicap from speaking Chinese well, compared to the ethnic speakers of the language.

    This is why we decided on the policy of ensuring that our standard in the Chinese language is not diluted further through the effluxion of time. We have decided therefore that the Chinese language should be preserved in the form of SAP

Column: 1128

schools and recently the promotion of the Chinese cultural elites that was perhaps to serve as a bulwark against the further erosion of our culture and heritage.

    It is perhaps unfortunate, Sir, that the promotion and discussion of the teaching of Chinese in schools in a high profile and significant manner, such as the promotion of SAP schools, cannot yet be carried out in Singapore at the moment without the risk of being misunderstood. As it is, the very suggestion of promoting Chinese cultural elites is seen by others as possibly raising a new generation of Chinese leaders in Singapore who have little or no contact with minority members and who then, when placed in a position of public policy making, make decisions which show very little sympathy for the others.

    Such fears, with all due respect, do not appear to be founded. In the first place, I believe that raising a new breed of cultural elites or the Chinese elites is not the same as raising political elites, or civil service elites. I have understood the term to mean, in the context of our recent debates, raising a group of Singaporeans who are highly skilled in the Chinese language, so that they in turn can act as custodians of the standard and quality of the spoken and written Chinese in Singapore.

    Secondly, even if some of these cultural elites do become policy makers, it would be wrong to assume that having spent six to 12 years in a Chinese speaking environment, these people will not have any sympathy for the minorities. We seem to assume that these people live in a vacuum and would have no contact with the minority races. We have forgotten that 80% of our Chinese in Singapore live in housing estates which are multi-racial in composition. We have also forgotten that we have to do National Service which is also multi-racial in composition. In my own experience, I went to a school that did not have many members of the minority groups. Most of my friends then were predominantly Chinese. It did not matter for me, because right from young, the school taught me to respect the customs and beliefs of others who are

Column: 1129

not like me. The society that I operated in believes in the multi-racial principle and expects me to conduct myself accordingly. When I served my country in national service, I had plenty of opportunity to interact with the minority members and I got along well with them. I never had any problem if I had to fight to save my fellow Singaporean who may not be a Chinese.

    Sir, Singapore is a multi-racial country and will continue to be so. Having said that, I would like to say that there are a number of principles that we should observe.

    First, we are never a melting pot of cultures and should never be.

    Secondly, we should maintain our distinct identity and let it evolve in its natural and different way. As I have said earlier, we can never be as Chinese as the Chinese in mainland China; and I am not sure whether we want to be. We should therefore not insist on maintaining standards at all costs, as it may come across as being chauvinistic to others. We should not be ashamed to say that as Chinese, our cultural practices have evolved in its own unique way.

    Thirdly, each ethnic group in Singapore must accept and respect the desire of other ethnic groups to maintain its own identity through its cultural practices, including the teaching of the mother tongue so long as these practices do not harm or affect the interest of the larger society. In this regard, we cannot demand, for instance, that schools run by the clan associations and which have a history of providing a total environment for the teaching of the mother tongue be required to teach non-Chinese as second language and, in the process, alter the character of the school. As long as there are enough schools in the area, there is no compelling reason why long established policies should change.
1.00 pm

    Fourthly, our belief in maintaining our separate and distinct identity should always be subordinated to the demands

Column: 1130

of national and social cohesion. While we want to preserve and promote our mother tongue and prevent it from being adulterated, we should be aware that rifts may be created within our society as well. We are at the moment beginning to see indications of this. Take the teaching of Chinese language, for instance. We have over the years evolved the teaching of the Chinese language to the extent that we have differentiated between those who are able to take Chinese at first level and those who are not. In class and status conscious Singapore, this is a constant source of pressure and unhappiness. And now, we have created a new super class of the Chinese elites, giving much concern to the others about how this would affect our multiracial society as we know it.

    Additionally, care should be given when relocating clan schools that do not offer Chinese as a second language to the residential neighbourhoods. It would surely be a recipe for unhappiness if the school was the only school within a one kilometre radius and the minority groups are told that they are not eligible to apply and would have to go elsewhere where they may not have any priority in admitting their children. I am not saying that our language policies at the moment have resulted in any undermining of our national unity that we enjoy today. However, I would say that if in maintaining our present language policies, there is a great deal of unhappiness to a point where social cohesion is eroded in the process, the Government should step back and reassess its bearings to see if it is worth the sacrifice.

    Sir, in reviewing the Ministry's policy on the teaching of mother tongue, I would urge the Minister to bear in mind what I have just said.

    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang)(In Malay): Sir, in the Ministry's efforts to improve the teaching of mother tongues, the quality of teachers should be given emphasis. This is relevant to all mother tongues.

Column: 1131



    On the issue of Malay language teaching in schools, the younger Malay teachers, like most other young teachers in Singapore, are likely to have had an English-based education and most would have taken Malay as a second language. With regard to this, how competent are they in teaching ML1 or higher level Malay?

    The Minister for Education has stated that the percentage of students taking ML1 will be increased from 20% to 30%. Are there currently enough Malay Language teachers to be able to cope with an increase of students from 350 at present levels to 500 in the next year? If we are short of Malay language teachers, how will the Ministry increase the number?

    Like other professions that are based on vernacular languages, for example, journalism in Mandarin, Tamil and Malay in Singapore, we are likely to see continued shortage of capable people to teach the mother tongues, particularly at the higher language level. We can always look at the possibility of recruiting suitable teachers from overseas to fill the need for such teachers. But we can actually still tap the local talent pool for language teaching if we provide the proper incentives. The Ministry should consider offering scholarship to `A' level holders who are deemed capable to teach the mother tongues at a higher level. At the same time, the Ministry should also state clearly that second language teachers who have the leadership potential stand a chance to be promoted not just up to the level of senior subject teacher, but also to the level of Principal or Vice-Principal.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan (Nominated Member)(In Mandarin): Sir, last year, the Government announced a new policy on the teaching of Chinese Language. Since then, there have been numerous debates, and both educators and laymen have expressed keen interest on the subject. Judging from the new policy promulgated, the Government's approach is very pragmatic for it not only concerns itself

Column: 1132

with the nurturing of Chinese elite, but also takes heed of the need for Chinese language to be learnt by everybody, and to create an environment conducive to the learning and application of Chinese.
